text:
```julia> module A
       using LinearAlgebra
       ldiv!(x) = 2
       end```
redefines a new ldiv! and doesn't error or warn, although it does error at the REPL. Shouldn't it? Sorry if this is a dumb question, I didn't find any discussion of it

text: the REPL helpfully tells me that, but it doesn't in a module

text:
julia> using LinearAlgebra

julia> ldiv!(x) = 2
ERROR: error in method definition: function LinearAlgebra.ldiv! must be explicitly imported to be extended

elements.text:
julia> using LinearAlgebra

julia> ldiv!(x) = 2
ERROR: error in method definition: function LinearAlgebra.ldiv! must be explicitly imported to be extended

text: I don't understand why it's illegal at the REPL and not in a module

elements.text: I don't understand why it's illegal at the REPL and not in a module

text: You want an error, "ERROR: error in method definition: function LinearAlgebra.ldiv! must be explicitly imported to be extended" to be thrown when you try to redefine `ldiv!` in a module A rather than in `Main` via the REPL?

text: that's what I would have expected yes

elements.text: that's what I would have expected yes

text: So I don't know about the appropriate messaging, but that would mean that packages can't have redefinitions of existing functions that have nothing to do with the environment they inherit, but have to contend with extending the package, which could potentially have an effect on other functions' behavior. Maybe I want two separate meanings of reshaping a tensor, `MyPkg.reshape` which does something different from  `Base.reshape`
